title: Non-stationary dynamics of interspike intervals in neuronal populations
summary: We study the joint dynamics of membrane potential and time since the last spike in a population of integrate-and-fire neurons using a population density framework. This leads to a two-dimensional Fokker-Planck equation that captures the evolution of the full neuronal state, along with a one-dimensional hierarchy of equations for the moments of the inter-spike interval (ISI). The formalism allows us to characterize the time-dependent ISI distribution, even when the population is far from stationarity, such as under time-varying external input or during network oscillations. By performing a perturbative expansion around the stationary state, we also derive an analytic expression for the linear response of the ISI distribution to weak input modulations.

AI.tldr: Analysis of integrate-and-fire neuron population dynamics using 2D Fokker-Planck equations and moment hierarchies for inter-spike interval distributions, with perturbation theory for linear response to input modulations.
AI.motivation: To understand the joint dynamics of membrane potential and time since last spike in neural populations, particularly for characterizing time-dependent inter-spike interval distributions during non-stationary conditions like time-varying inputs or network oscillations.
AI.method: Population density framework leading to a two-dimensional Fokker-Planck equation for neuronal state evolution, coupled with a one-dimensional hierarchy of equations for inter-spike interval moments. Perturbative expansion around stationary state to derive analytic expressions for linear response.
AI.result: Developed formalism capable of characterizing time-dependent ISI distributions even far from stationarity. Derived analytic expression for linear response of ISI distribution to weak input modulations through perturbation theory.
AI.conclusion: The population density approach provides a comprehensive framework for analyzing integrate-and-fire neuron dynamics, enabling characterization of ISI distributions under non-stationary conditions and quantification of neural population responses to input modulations.

title: The disordered Su-Schrieffer-Heeger model
summary: Quantum topology categorizes physical systems in integer invariants, which are robust to some deformations and certain types of disorder. A prime example is the Su-Schrieffer-Heeger (SSH) model, which has two distinct topological phases, the trivial phase with no edge states and the non-trivial phase with zero-energy edge states. The energy dispersion of the SSH model is dominated by a gap around zero energy, which suppresses the transmission. This exponential suppression of the transmission with system length is determined by the Lyapounov exponent. Here we find an analytical expression of the Lyapounov as a function of energy in the presence of both diagonal and off-diagonal disorder. We obtain this result by finding a recurrence relation for the local density, which can be averaged over different disorder configurations. There is excellent agreement between our analytical expression and the numerical results over a wide range of disorder strengths and disorder types. The real space winding number is evaluated as a function of off-diagonal and on-site disorder for possible applications of quantum topology.

AI.tldr: Analytical expression derived for Lyapunov exponent in disordered SSH model, enabling calculation of transmission suppression and topological invariants under various disorder types.
AI.motivation: Quantum topological systems exhibit robust integer invariants, but understanding how disorder affects transmission properties and topological phases requires analytical tools beyond numerical simulations.
AI.method: Derived recurrence relation for local density, averaged over disorder configurations to obtain analytical expression for Lyapunov exponent as function of energy in presence of both diagonal (on-site) and off-diagonal disorder.
AI.result: Excellent agreement between analytical expression and numerical results across wide range of disorder strengths and types; real space winding number evaluated as function of disorder for quantum topology applications.
AI.conclusion: Analytical framework established for calculating transmission properties and topological invariants in disordered SSH models, providing tools for quantum topology applications under realistic disorder conditions.

title: Novel exact solutions of the Duffing equation: stability analysis and application to real non-linear deformation tests
summary: In this study, novel exact solutions of the Duffing equation with their phase portraits have been proposed and reasoned. It is shown that phase trajectories are initially elliptical and become distorted in the unstable area within the growth of the variable parameter. Instability criteria of identified solutions have been determined together with the Fourier series transformation up to the first and high harmonics in a sense of the physical interpretation. An explicit form for the differential operator, corresponding to considered functions, has been derived with evaluation of its main functional spectrum. Non-isothermal creep tests of different materials were completely described using the Duffing equation via noted solutions up to the fracture as processes with personal deformation response. We successfully examined a relationship between the thermal and magnetic properties of the ferromagnetic amorphous alloy under its non-linear deformation, using the critical exponents. With a high linear correlation between our model and experiments, behaviour of organic and metallic systems is well predicted at the same thermo-mechanical testing conditions on the mesoscale.

AI.tldr: Novel exact solutions for Duffing equation with phase portraits, instability criteria, Fourier analysis, and application to non-isothermal creep tests and ferromagnetic alloy deformation.
AI.motivation: To develop exact solutions for the Duffing equation that can describe complex physical phenomena including non-isothermal creep behavior and non-linear deformation in materials, particularly focusing on phase portrait analysis and instability characterization.
AI.method: Derived novel exact solutions of Duffing equation with phase portraits, determined instability criteria, performed Fourier series transformation to first and high harmonics, derived explicit form of differential operator with functional spectrum evaluation, applied to non-isothermal creep tests and ferromagnetic amorphous alloy deformation analysis.
AI.result: Phase trajectories are initially elliptical and become distorted in unstable regions as variable parameter grows; established instability criteria; developed explicit differential operator; successfully described non-isothermal creep tests up to fracture; examined relationship between thermal and magnetic properties in ferromagnetic amorphous alloy using critical exponents; high linear correlation between model and experiments.
AI.conclusion: The Duffing equation with proposed exact solutions effectively describes complex material behaviors including non-isothermal creep and non-linear deformation in both organic and metallic systems, with good predictive capability under thermo-mechanical testing conditions at mesoscale.

title: Quantization of Physical Interaction Strengths via Singular Moduli
summary: Since the 2019 redefinition of the SI units, precision metrology has sought to anchor all physical quantities to fundamental constants and integer invariants. While the optical frequency comb revolutionized timekeeping by discretizing the continuum of light into countable teeth, and the Quantum Hall Effect standardized resistance via topological invariants, a comparable standard for interaction strength remains elusive. Currently, measuring the coupling constant ($g$) between quantum systems is an estimation problem, inherently subject to drift, noise, and fabrication variance. Here, we introduce Interaction Metrology, a protocol that transforms the measurement of coupling strengths from an analog estimation into a topological counting problem. By engineering a specific class of algebraic catastrophe -- the Unimodal $X_9$ singularity -- in a driven-dissipative lattice, we prove that the system's interaction moduli are topologically forced to take discrete, quantized values, forming a "Geometric $k$-Comb." We derive the universality class of this quantization, showing that it arises from the discrepancy between the Milnor ($μ$) and Tjurina ($τ$) numbers of the effective potential, a strictly non-Hermitian effect forbidden in standard quantum mechanics. Finally, we provide an ab-initio blueprint for a silicon nitride implementation, demonstrating that this quantization is robust against disorder levels exceeding current foundry tolerances. This discovery establishes a universal standard for force sensing and quantum logic gates, enabling the calibration of interaction strengths with topological certainty.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces Interaction Metrology, a protocol that transforms coupling strength measurement from analog estimation to topological counting by engineering an algebraic catastrophe (Unimodal X₉ singularity) to force interaction moduli into discrete, quantized values.
AI.motivation: After the 2019 SI redefinition anchoring quantities to fundamental constants, a standard for interaction strength remains elusive. Current coupling constant (g) measurements suffer from drift, noise, and fabrication variance as estimation problems.
AI.method: Engineers a specific algebraic catastrophe (Unimodal X₉ singularity) in a driven-dissipative lattice to force interaction moduli into discrete, quantized values forming a "Geometric k-Comb." Derives the universality class from the discrepancy between Milnor (μ) and Tjurina (τ) numbers of the effective potential, a strictly non-Hermitian effect. Provides a silicon nitride implementation blueprint.
AI.result: Interaction moduli are topologically forced to take discrete, quantized values. The quantization arises from the μ-τ discrepancy, a non-Hermitian effect forbidden in standard quantum mechanics. The quantization is robust against disorder levels exceeding current foundry tolerances.
AI.conclusion: Establishes a universal standard for force sensing and quantum logic gates, enabling calibration of interaction strengths with topological certainty, analogous to how optical frequency combs revolutionized timekeeping and Quantum Hall Effect standardized resistance.

title: Graphicality of power-law and double power-law degree sequences
summary: The graphicality problem -- whether or not a sequence of integers can be used to create a simple graph -- is a key question in network theory and combinatorics, with many important practical applications. In this work, we study the graphicality of degree sequences distributed as a power-law with a size-dependent cutoff and as a double power-law with a size-dependent crossover. We combine the application of exact sufficient conditions for graphicality with heuristic conditions for nongraphicality which allow us to elucidate the physical reasons why some sequences are not graphical. For single power-laws we recover the known phase-diagram, we highlight the subtle interplay of distinct mechanisms violating graphicality and we explain why the infinite-size limit behavior is in some cases very far from being observed for finite sequences. For double power-laws we derive the graphicality of infinite sequences for all possible values of the degree exponents $γ_1$ and $γ_2$, uncovering a rich phase-diagram and pointing out the existence of five qualitatively distinct ways graphicality can be violated. The validity of theoretical arguments is supported by extensive numerical analysis.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes graphicality conditions for power-law degree sequences with size-dependent cutoffs and double power-laws, revealing complex phase diagrams and distinct mechanisms for graphicality violation.
AI.motivation: The graphicality problem is fundamental in network theory and combinatorics with practical applications. Understanding when degree sequences can form simple graphs is crucial for modeling real-world networks, especially those with power-law degree distributions which are common in complex systems.
AI.method: Combines exact sufficient conditions for graphicality with heuristic conditions for nongraphicality. Analyzes single power-laws with size-dependent cutoffs and double power-laws with size-dependent crossovers. Uses theoretical arguments supported by extensive numerical analysis.
AI.result: For single power-laws: recovers known phase diagram, highlights subtle interplay of distinct graphicality-violating mechanisms, explains why infinite-size limit behavior differs from finite sequences. For double power-laws: derives graphicality conditions for infinite sequences across all degree exponents γ₁ and γ₂, revealing rich phase diagram with five qualitatively distinct ways graphicality can be violated.
AI.conclusion: The study provides comprehensive understanding of graphicality for power-law degree sequences, uncovering complex phase behavior and multiple mechanisms for graphicality violation, with implications for modeling real-world networks with heavy-tailed degree distributions.

title: Landauer cost in a continuous vacuum/no-vacuum measurement
summary: We study the thermodynamic cost of maintaining a continuous binary record of a vacuum or no-vacuum measurement. Modeling the monitoring as a time-binned click or no-click process with finite bandwidth, we treat the outcomes as a classical register that is reset after each bin. Landauer's principle then yields an operational lower bound on the dissipated heat rate set by the Shannon entropy rate of the measurement record. We discuss the role of coarse-graining, extend the analysis to many monitored modes, including correlations and compressibility, and provide parameter estimates for circuit-QED photon monitoring, with a speculative horizon-based bookkeeping illustration.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes a thermodynamic lower bound on heat dissipation for continuous quantum measurement monitoring, applying Landauer's principle to measurement records treated as classical registers that require periodic resetting.
AI.motivation: To quantify the fundamental thermodynamic cost of maintaining continuous measurement records in quantum systems, specifically for vacuum/no-vacuum monitoring, which has implications for quantum information processing and measurement theory.
AI.method: Model continuous monitoring as a time-binned click/no-click process with finite bandwidth, treat outcomes as a classical register reset after each bin, apply Landauer's principle to derive heat dissipation bounds based on Shannon entropy rates of measurement records.
AI.result: Derived operational lower bound on dissipated heat rate set by Shannon entropy rate of measurement record; extended analysis to many monitored modes including correlations and compressibility; provided parameter estimates for circuit-QED photon monitoring.
AI.conclusion: Continuous quantum measurement monitoring has fundamental thermodynamic costs governed by Landauer's principle, with dissipation rates bounded by information entropy rates of measurement records, applicable to practical quantum measurement systems.

title: Probabilistic Computers for Neural Quantum States
summary: Neural quantum states efficiently represent many-body wavefunctions with neural networks, but the cost of Monte Carlo sampling limits their scaling to large system sizes. Here we address this challenge by combining sparse Boltzmann machine architectures with probabilistic computing hardware. We implement a probabilistic computer on field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) and use it as a fast sampler for energy-based neural quantum states. For the two-dimensional transverse-field Ising model at criticality, we obtain accurate ground-state energies for lattices up to 80 $\times$ 80 (6400 spins) using a custom multi-FPGA cluster. Furthermore, we introduce a dual-sampling algorithm to train deep Boltzmann machines, replacing intractable marginalization with conditional sampling over auxiliary layers. This enables the training of sparse deep models and improves parameter efficiency relative to shallow networks. Using this algorithm, we train deep Boltzmann machines for a system with 35 $\times$ 35 (1225 spins). Together, these results demonstrate that probabilistic hardware can overcome the sampling bottleneck in variational simulation of quantum many-body systems, opening a path to larger system sizes and deeper variational architectures.

AI.tldr: Combining sparse Boltzmann machines with FPGA-based probabilistic computing hardware enables efficient sampling for neural quantum states, achieving accurate ground-state energies for large 2D Ising systems up to 6400 spins and introducing a dual-sampling algorithm for training deep Boltzmann machines.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to overcome the sampling bottleneck in neural quantum states, where Monte Carlo sampling costs limit scaling to large system sizes in variational quantum many-body simulations.
AI.method: The method combines sparse Boltzmann machine architectures with custom FPGA-based probabilistic computing hardware for fast sampling. A dual-sampling algorithm is introduced for training deep Boltzmann machines, replacing intractable marginalization with conditional sampling over auxiliary layers.
AI.result: Accurate ground-state energies obtained for 2D transverse-field Ising model at criticality up to 80×80 lattices (6400 spins) using multi-FPGA cluster. Deep Boltzmann machines trained for 35×35 systems (1225 spins) with improved parameter efficiency relative to shallow networks.
AI.conclusion: Probabilistic hardware can overcome the sampling bottleneck in variational simulation of quantum many-body systems, enabling larger system sizes and deeper variational architectures for neural quantum states.

title: Aliphatic Chains as One-Dimensional XY Spin Chains
summary: Spin waves are propagating disturbances of spin order in lattices with nearest-neighbor interactions. They are traditionally observed in magnetically ordered solids using inelastic neutron, light, or electron scattering, and ferromagnetic resonance. Here, we show that analogous spin dynamics can arise in liquid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) of molecules containing aliphatic chains. In such molecules, each CH_2 group must have a distinct chemical shift and be magnetically inequivalent via out-of-pair couplings. Under these conditions, singlet state populations of geminal protons propagate along (CH_2)_n segments forming magnetically silent spin waves. For a chain with translational symmetry, the spin Hamiltonian factorizes into subspaces formally equivalent to the one-dimensional XY model. This correspondence yields analytic expressions for eigenstates and eigenenergies in a spectroscopy we term spin-chain zero-quantum NMR. We identify molecular systems in which these conditions are met. Their collective dynamics rapidly exceed classical computational tractability, making them targets for quantum-computer simulations of spin transport and many-body dynamics.

AI.tldr: Spin wave dynamics analogous to solid-state systems can be observed in liquid-state NMR of aliphatic chains with specific magnetic inequivalence conditions, enabling quantum simulations of spin transport.
AI.motivation: To demonstrate that spin wave phenomena traditionally observed in magnetically ordered solids can also occur in liquid-state NMR systems, specifically in molecules with aliphatic chains, and to establish these systems as platforms for studying quantum many-body dynamics.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis of NMR systems where CH₂ groups have distinct chemical shifts and magnetic inequivalence via out-of-pair couplings, leading to factorization of the spin Hamiltonian into subspaces equivalent to the 1D XY model, enabling analytic solutions for eigenstates and eigenenergies in spin-chain zero-quantum NMR spectroscopy.
AI.result: Identification of molecular systems meeting the required conditions where singlet state populations propagate along (CH₂)ₙ segments as magnetically silent spin waves, with collective dynamics that rapidly exceed classical computational tractability.
AI.conclusion: Aliphatic chain molecules with specific magnetic properties can exhibit spin wave dynamics analogous to solid-state systems, making them promising targets for quantum computer simulations of spin transport and many-body quantum dynamics.

authors: D. M. F. Bischoff van Heemskerck
title: Euler-Korteweg vortices: A fluid-mechanical analogue to the Schrödinger and Klein-Gordon equations
summary: Quantum theory and relativity exhibit several formal analogies with fluid mechanics. This paper examines under which conditions a classical fluid model may reproduce the most basic mathematical formalism of both theories. By assuming that the angular momentum of an irrotational vortex in an inviscid, barotropic, isothermal fluid with sound speed c is equal in magnitude to the reduced Planck constant, and incorporating Korteweg capillary stress, a complex wave equation describing the momentum and continuity equations of a Euler-Korteweg vortex is obtained. When uniform convection is introduced, the weak field approximation of this wave equation is equivalent to Schrödinger's equation. The model is shown to yield classical analogues to de Broglie wavelength, the Einstein-Planck relation, the Born rule and the uncertainty principle. Accounting for the retarded propagation of the wavefield of a vortex in convection produces the Lorentz transformation and the Klein-Gordon equation, with Schrödinger's equation appearing as the low-Mach-number limit. These results demonstrate that, under explicit assumptions, a classical continuum can reproduce the mathematical formalism of quantum and relativistic theory in their simplest form, without assuming the postulates principal to those theories.

AI.tldr: Classical fluid model reproduces quantum and relativistic formalism through vortex dynamics with specific assumptions about angular momentum and capillary stress.
AI.motivation: To explore whether classical fluid mechanics can reproduce the mathematical formalism of quantum theory and relativity without assuming their fundamental postulates, examining formal analogies between these theories.
AI.method: Develops a classical fluid model using an irrotational vortex in an inviscid, barotropic, isothermal fluid with sound speed c, assuming vortex angular momentum equals reduced Planck constant, and incorporates Korteweg capillary stress to derive a complex wave equation from Euler-Korteweg vortex momentum and continuity equations.
AI.result: The model yields classical analogues to key quantum concepts: de Broglie wavelength, Einstein-Planck relation, Born rule, and uncertainty principle. With uniform convection, weak field approximation produces Schrödinger's equation. Accounting for retarded wavefield propagation yields Lorentz transformation and Klein-Gordon equation, with Schrödinger's equation as low-Mach-number limit.
AI.conclusion: Under explicit assumptions about vortex angular momentum and capillary stress, a classical continuum can reproduce the mathematical formalism of quantum and relativistic theory in simplest form without assuming their fundamental postulates, demonstrating formal analogies between fluid mechanics and fundamental physics theories.

title: DifGa: Differentiable Error Mitigation for Multi-Mode Gaussian and Non-Gaussian Noise in Quantum Photonic Circuits
summary: We introduce DifGa, a fully differentiable error-mitigation framework for continuous-variable (CV) quantum photonic circuits operating under Gaussian loss and weak non-Gaussian noise. The approach is demonstrated using analytic simulations with the default.gaussian backend of PennyLane, where quantum states are represented by first and second moments and optimized end-to-end via automatic differentiation. Gaussian loss is modeled as a beam splitter interaction with an environmental vacuum mode of transmissivity $η\in [0.3,0.95]$, while non-Gaussian phase noise is incorporated through a differentiable Monte-Carlo mixture of random phase rotations with jitter amplitudes $δ\in [0,0.7]$. The core architecture employs a multi-mode Gaussian circuit consisting of a signal, ancilla, and environment mode. Input states are prepared using squeezing and displacement operations with parameters $(r_s,\varphi_s,α)=(0.60,0.30,0.80)$ and $(r_a,\varphi_a)=(0.40,0.10)$, followed by an entangling beam splitter with angles $(θ,φ)=(0.70,0.20)$. Error mitigation is achieved by appending a six-parameter trainable Gaussian recovery layer comprising local phase rotations and displacements, optimized by minimizing a quadratic loss on the signal-mode quadratures $\langle \hat{x}_0\rangle$ and $\langle \hat{p}_0\rangle$ using gradient descent with fixed learning rate $0.06$ and identical initialization across experiments. Under pure Gaussian loss, the optimized recovery suppresses reconstruction error to near machine precision ($<10^{-30}$) for moderate loss ($η\ge 0.5$). When non-Gaussian phase noise is present, noise-aware training using Monte Carlo averaging yields robust generalization, reducing error by more than an order of magnitude compared to Gaussian-trained recovery at large phase jitter. Runtime benchmarks confirm linear scaling with the number of Monte Carlo samples.

AI.tldr: DifGa is a differentiable error-mitigation framework for continuous-variable quantum photonic circuits that optimizes Gaussian recovery operations via automatic differentiation to combat Gaussian loss and weak non-Gaussian phase noise.
AI.motivation: Continuous-variable quantum photonic circuits suffer from Gaussian loss (photon loss) and weak non-Gaussian noise, which degrade quantum state quality and measurement outcomes. Existing error mitigation methods may not be fully differentiable or optimized end-to-end for these specific noise types.
AI.method: The framework uses a multi-mode Gaussian circuit with signal, ancilla, and environment modes. Gaussian loss is modeled as beam splitter interaction with vacuum environment, while non-Gaussian phase noise uses Monte-Carlo mixture of random phase rotations. A six-parameter trainable Gaussian recovery layer (phase rotations and displacements) is appended and optimized via gradient descent with quadratic loss on signal-mode quadratures.
AI.result: Under pure Gaussian loss, optimized recovery suppresses reconstruction error to near machine precision (<10^{-30}) for moderate loss (η≥0.5). With non-Gaussian phase noise, noise-aware training reduces error by more than an order of magnitude compared to Gaussian-trained recovery at large phase jitter. Runtime scales linearly with Monte Carlo samples.
AI.conclusion: DifGa provides an effective differentiable framework for error mitigation in CV quantum photonic circuits, achieving near-perfect recovery for Gaussian loss and robust generalization to non-Gaussian phase noise through end-to-end optimization.

title: Efficient simulation of logical magic state preparation protocols
summary: Developing space- and time-efficient logical magic state preparation protocols will likely be an essential step towards building a large-scale fault-tolerant quantum computer. Motivated by this need, we introduce a scalable method for simulating logical magic state preparation protocols under the standard circuit-level noise model. When applied to protocols based on code switching, magic state cultivation, and magic state distillation, our method yields a complexity polynomial in (i) the number of qubits and (ii) the non-stabilizerness, e.g., stabilizer rank or Pauli rank, of the target encoded magic state. The efficiency of our simulation method is rooted in a curious fact: every circuit-level Pauli error in these protocols propagates to a Clifford error at the end. This property is satisfied by a large family of protocols, including those that repeatedly measure a transversal Clifford that squares to a Pauli. We provide a proof-of-principle numerical simulation that prepares a magic state using such logical Clifford measurements. Our work enables practical simulation of logical magic state preparation protocols without resorting to approximations or resource-intensive state-vector simulations.

AI.tldr: Scalable simulation method for logical magic state preparation protocols with polynomial complexity in qubit count and non-stabilizerness, enabling practical simulation without approximations or full state-vector methods.
AI.motivation: Developing efficient logical magic state preparation protocols is crucial for building large-scale fault-tolerant quantum computers, requiring scalable simulation methods to evaluate these protocols under realistic noise models.
AI.method: Introduces a scalable simulation method for logical magic state preparation protocols under circuit-level noise model. The method leverages the property that circuit-level Pauli errors propagate to Clifford errors at the end, particularly applicable to protocols measuring transversal Cliffords that square to Paulis. Applied to code switching, magic state cultivation, and distillation protocols.
AI.result: Achieves polynomial complexity in both number of qubits and non-stabilizerness (stabilizer rank or Pauli rank) of target magic state. Provides proof-of-principle numerical simulation preparing magic state using logical Clifford measurements.
AI.conclusion: Enables practical simulation of logical magic state preparation protocols without approximations or resource-intensive state-vector simulations, facilitating development of space- and time-efficient protocols for fault-tolerant quantum computing.

title: Mermin Devices for Generalized Dicke States
summary: We present here several new exact results for a number of entangled states: the W-state of three qubits and its generalization -- Dicke states for more than three qubits. We derive these results by bounding the expected values of the Bell-Mermin operators. We review the three qubit GHZ Mermin device, make its generalization to four qubits, and then construct analogous Mermin devices for the generalized Dicke states of three and four qubits. As a result of studying if their operations can be fully explained by Mermin's instructional sets, we show that the GHZ and Dicke states of three qubits and the GHZ state of four qubits do not allow such a description. However, among the two generalized Dicke states of four qubits, one does allow and the other does not allow such a description.

AI.tldr: Analysis of Bell-Mermin operators for W-states and Dicke states shows quantum nonlocality: GHZ and Dicke states of 3 qubits and GHZ of 4 qubits violate Mermin's instructional sets, while only one of two 4-qubit Dicke states allows such classical description.
AI.motivation: To investigate quantum nonlocality in multipartite entangled states by analyzing whether their correlations can be explained by Mermin's instructional sets (classical hidden variable models), focusing on W-states and generalized Dicke states.
AI.method: Derive exact bounds on expected values of Bell-Mermin operators for W-states and Dicke states. Generalize the three-qubit GHZ Mermin device to four qubits, then construct analogous Mermin devices for generalized Dicke states of three and four qubits. Test if operations can be fully explained by Mermin's instructional sets.
AI.result: GHZ and Dicke states of three qubits and GHZ state of four qubits cannot be described by Mermin's instructional sets (demonstrate quantum nonlocality). Among two generalized Dicke states of four qubits, one allows such classical description while the other does not.
AI.conclusion: Different multipartite entangled states exhibit varying degrees of quantum nonlocality: while most tested states violate classical hidden variable models, some specific Dicke states of four qubits surprisingly admit Mermin's instructional set description, revealing nuanced structure in quantum correlations.

title: Syndrome aware mitigation of logical errors
summary:
Broad applications of quantum computers will require error correction (EC). However, quantum hardware roadmaps indicate that physical qubit numbers will remain limited in the foreseeable future, leading to residual logical errors that limit the size and accuracy of achievable computations. Recent work suggested logical error mitigation (LEM), which applies known error mitigation (EM) methods to logical errors, eliminating their effect at the cost of a runtime overhead. Improving the efficiency of LEM is crucial for increasing the logical circuit volumes it enables to execute.
  We introduce syndrome-aware logical error mitigation (SALEM), which makes use of the syndrome data measured during error correction, when mitigating the logical errors. The runtime overhead of SALEM is exponentially lower than that of previously proposed LEM schemes, resulting in significantly increased circuit volumes that can be executed accurately. Notably, relative to the routinely used combination of error correction and syndrome rejection (post-selection), SALEM increases the size of reliably executable computations by orders of magnitude. In this practical setting in which space and time are both resources that need to be optimized, our work reveals a surprising phenomenon: SALEM, which tightly combines EC with EM, can outperform physical EM even above the standard fault-tolerance threshold. Thus, SALEM can make use of EC in regimes of physical error rates at which EC is commonly deemed useless.

AI.tldr: SALEM (Syndrome-Aware Logical Error Mitigation) is a new technique that uses syndrome data from quantum error correction to exponentially reduce runtime overhead compared to previous logical error mitigation methods, enabling significantly larger quantum computations.
AI.motivation: Quantum hardware will remain limited in physical qubit numbers in the near future, leading to residual logical errors that constrain computational size and accuracy. Existing logical error mitigation (LEM) methods have high runtime overhead, limiting their practical utility for executing larger quantum circuits.
AI.method: SALEM integrates syndrome data measured during quantum error correction into the error mitigation process. By leveraging this additional information about error patterns, it achieves more efficient mitigation of logical errors compared to previous LEM approaches that treated logical errors as black boxes.
AI.result: SALEM reduces runtime overhead exponentially compared to previous LEM schemes, enabling orders-of-magnitude larger circuit volumes to be executed accurately. It outperforms the standard combination of error correction with syndrome rejection (post-selection) and can even surpass physical error mitigation above the standard fault-tolerance threshold.
AI.conclusion: SALEM demonstrates that tightly combining error correction with error mitigation can make error correction useful in regimes where it was previously considered ineffective, enabling practical quantum computation with limited physical qubit resources by optimizing both space and time resources simultaneously.

title: Quantum Error Mitigation with Attention Graph Transformers for Burgers Equation Solvers on NISQ Hardware
summary: We present a hybrid quantum-classical framework augmented with learned error mitigation for solving the viscous Burgers equation on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) hardware. Using the Cole-Hopf transformation, the nonlinear Burgers equation is mapped to a diffusion equation, discretized on uniform grids, and encoded into a quantum state whose time evolution is approximated via Trotterized nearest-neighbor circuits implemented in Qiskit. Quantum simulations are executed on noisy Aer backends and IBM superconducting quantum devices and are benchmarked against high-accuracy classical solutions obtained using a Krylov-based solver applied to the corresponding discretized Hamiltonian. From measured quantum amplitudes, we reconstruct the velocity field and evaluate physical and numerical diagnostics, including the L2 error, shock location, and dissipation rate, both with and without zero-noise extrapolation (ZNE). To enable data-driven error mitigation, we construct a large parametric dataset by sweeping viscosity, time step, grid resolution, and boundary conditions, producing matched tuples of noisy, ZNE-corrected, hardware, and classical solutions together with detailed circuit metadata. Leveraging this dataset, we train an attention-based graph neural network that incorporates circuit structure, light-cone information, global circuit parameters, and noisy quantum outputs to predict error-mitigated solutions. Across a wide range of parameters, the learned model consistently reduces the discrepancy between quantum and classical solutions beyond what is achieved by ZNE alone. We discuss extensions of this approach to higher-dimensional Burgers systems and more general quantum partial differential equation solvers, highlighting learned error mitigation as a promising complement to physics-based noise reduction techniques on NISQ devices.

AI.tldr: Hybrid quantum-classical framework with learned error mitigation solves viscous Burgers equation on NISQ hardware using Cole-Hopf transformation, Trotterized circuits, and attention-based GNNs trained on parametric datasets to outperform zero-noise extrapolation.
AI.motivation: To develop practical quantum algorithms for solving nonlinear PDEs on NISQ devices by addressing noise limitations through learned error mitigation techniques that complement physics-based approaches.
AI.method: 1) Use Cole-Hopf transformation to map nonlinear Burgers equation to linear diffusion equation; 2) Discretize on uniform grids and encode into quantum states; 3) Implement time evolution via Trotterized nearest-neighbor circuits in Qiskit; 4) Execute on noisy Aer backends and IBM quantum devices; 5) Create parametric dataset by sweeping viscosity, time step, grid resolution, and boundary conditions; 6) Train attention-based graph neural network incorporating circuit structure, light-cone information, global parameters, and noisy outputs to predict error-mitigated solutions.
AI.result: Learned error mitigation consistently reduces discrepancy between quantum and classical solutions beyond zero-noise extrapolation alone across wide parameter ranges. Model incorporates circuit metadata and noisy outputs to predict corrected solutions, demonstrating effectiveness on both simulated noisy backends and actual IBM quantum hardware.
AI.conclusion: Learned error mitigation is a promising complement to physics-based noise reduction techniques for quantum PDE solvers on NISQ devices, with potential extensions to higher-dimensional Burgers systems and more general quantum PDE solvers.

title: Squeezed states for Frenkel-like two-fermion composite bosons
summary: We investigate squeezed states of composite bosons (cobosons) formed by pairs of spin-$1/2$ fermions, with emphasis on Frenkel-like cobosons. While squeezing for standard bosonic modes is well established, its extension to cobosons requires accounting for Pauli blocking and the resulting non-canonical commutation algebra. Building on earlier constructions of coboson coherent states, we define squeezed cobosons as eigenstates of a Bogoliubov transformed coboson operator and derive explicit expressions for the associated quadrature variances. We show that the underlying fermionic structure leads to state-dependent modifications of the Heisenberg--Robertson uncertainty bound, which may fall below the canonical bosonic limit without implying any violation of uncertainty principles. Numerical results based on finite-dimensional matrix representations illustrate how these effects constrain the attainable squeezing. Our framework is relevant to composite boson systems such as tightly bound electron-hole pairs and provides a physically transparent setting to probe compositeness through observable quadrature fluctuations.

AI.tldr: Squeezed states of composite bosons (cobosons) are investigated, showing that fermionic structure modifies squeezing limits and uncertainty bounds compared to standard bosons.
AI.motivation: While squeezing for standard bosonic modes is well established, extending squeezing concepts to composite bosons (cobosons formed by fermion pairs) requires accounting for Pauli blocking and non-canonical commutation algebra. The framework is relevant to composite boson systems like tightly bound electron-hole pairs.
AI.method: Building on earlier coboson coherent state constructions, define squeezed cobosons as eigenstates of Bogoliubov transformed coboson operators. Derive explicit expressions for quadrature variances and analyze how fermionic structure modifies uncertainty bounds. Use finite-dimensional matrix representations for numerical analysis.
AI.result: The fermionic structure leads to state-dependent modifications of the Heisenberg-Robertson uncertainty bound, which may fall below the canonical bosonic limit without violating uncertainty principles. Numerical results illustrate how these effects constrain attainable squeezing.
AI.conclusion: The framework provides a physically transparent setting to probe compositeness through observable quadrature fluctuations in composite boson systems, showing how Pauli blocking and non-canonical algebra fundamentally modify squeezing properties compared to elementary bosons.

title: Tensor Computing Interface: An Application-Oriented, Lightweight Interface for Portable High-Performance Tensor Network Applications
summary: Tensor networks (TNs) are a central computational tool in quantum science and artificial intelligence. However, the lack of unified software interface across tensor-computing frameworks severely limits the portability of TN applications, coupling algorithmic development to specific hardware and software back ends. To address this challenge, we introduce the Tensor Computing Interface (TCI) -- an application-oriented, lightweight application programming interface designed to enable framework-independent, high-performance TN applications. TCI provides a well-defined type system that abstracts tensor objects together with a minimal yet expressive set of core functions covering essential tensor manipulations and tensor linear-algebra operations. Through numerical demonstrations on representative tensor-network applications, we show that codes written against TCI can be migrated seamlessly across heterogeneous hardware and software platforms while achieving performance comparable to native framework implementations. We further release an open-source implementation of TCI based on \textit{Cytnx}, demonstrating its practicality and ease of integration with existing tensor-computing frameworks.

AI.tldr: TCI is a lightweight API that enables framework-independent, high-performance tensor network applications by abstracting tensor objects and providing essential operations, allowing seamless migration across hardware/software platforms.
AI.motivation: The lack of unified software interface across tensor-computing frameworks severely limits portability of tensor network applications, coupling algorithmic development to specific hardware and software back ends.
AI.method: Introduces Tensor Computing Interface (TCI) - an application-oriented, lightweight API with a well-defined type system that abstracts tensor objects and provides a minimal yet expressive set of core functions covering essential tensor manipulations and tensor linear-algebra operations.
AI.result: Numerical demonstrations show that codes written against TCI can be migrated seamlessly across heterogeneous hardware and software platforms while achieving performance comparable to native framework implementations. An open-source implementation based on Cytnx demonstrates practicality and ease of integration.
AI.conclusion: TCI successfully addresses the portability challenge in tensor network computing by providing a framework-independent interface that maintains high performance while enabling cross-platform compatibility.

title: Geometric View of One-Dimensional Quantum Mechanics
summary: We apply De Haro's Geometric View of Theories to one of the simplest quantum systems: a spinless particle on a line and on a circle. The classical phase space M = T*Q is taken as the base of a trivial Hilbert bundle E ~ M x H, and the familiar position and momentum representations are realised as different global trivialisations of this bundle. The Fourier transform appears as a fibrewise unitary transition function, so that the standard position-momentum duality is made precise as a change of coordinates on a single geometric object. For the circle, we also discuss twisted boundary conditions and show how a twist parameter can be incorporated either as a fixed boundary condition or as a base coordinate, in which case it gives rise to a flat U(H)-connection with nontrivial holonomy. These examples provide a concrete illustration of how the Geometric View organises quantum-mechanical representations and dualities in geometric terms.

AI.tldr: The paper applies De Haro's Geometric View of Theories to quantum systems (particle on line/circle), showing how position/momentum representations are different trivializations of a Hilbert bundle over classical phase space, with Fourier transform as transition function.
AI.motivation: To provide concrete illustrations of how De Haro's Geometric View of Theories organizes quantum-mechanical representations and dualities in geometric terms, using simple quantum systems as examples.
AI.method: Apply Geometric View to spinless particle on line and circle: use classical phase space M = T*Q as base of trivial Hilbert bundle E ~ M x H; realize position/momentum representations as different global trivializations; treat Fourier transform as fibrewise unitary transition function; for circle, incorporate twist parameter either as fixed boundary condition or base coordinate.
AI.result: Standard position-momentum duality is made precise as change of coordinates on single geometric object; for circle, twist parameter can be incorporated as base coordinate giving rise to flat U(H)-connection with nontrivial holonomy.
AI.conclusion: These examples demonstrate how Geometric View provides geometric framework for organizing quantum representations and dualities, showing Fourier transform as transition function and position-momentum duality as coordinate change on Hilbert bundle.

title: Towards Quantum Machine Learning of Lattice Boltzmann Collision Operators for Fluid Dynamic Simulations
summary: We attempt the use of a unitary operator to approximate the lattice Boltzmann collision operator. We use a modified amplitude encoding to bypass the renormalization that would have required classical processing at every step (thus eroding any quantum advantage to be had). We describe the hard-wiring of the lattice Boltzmann symmetries into the quantum circuit and show that, for the specific case of the cavity flow, approximating the nonlinear system is limited to low velocities. These findings may help us understand better the possibilities of nonlinear simulations on a quantum computer, and also pave the way for a discussion on how quantum machine learning might be harnessed to address more complex problems.

AI.tldr: A quantum approach to approximate the lattice Boltzmann collision operator using unitary operators and modified amplitude encoding, with application to cavity flow limited to low velocities.
AI.motivation: To explore quantum computing for nonlinear simulations by approximating the lattice Boltzmann collision operator, bypassing classical renormalization requirements that would erode quantum advantage.
AI.method: Use of unitary operator approximation with modified amplitude encoding to avoid classical renormalization; hard-wiring of lattice Boltzmann symmetries into quantum circuits; application to cavity flow simulation.
AI.result: For cavity flow, approximating the nonlinear system is limited to low velocities; the approach demonstrates feasibility but with current limitations on velocity range.
AI.conclusion: The findings provide insights into nonlinear simulation possibilities on quantum computers and suggest pathways for using quantum machine learning to address more complex problems.

title: One-Shot Structured Pruning of Quantum Neural Networks via $q$-Group Engineering and Quantum Geometric Metrics
summary:
Quantum neural networks (QNNs) suffer from severe gate-level redundancy, which hinders their deployment on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices. In this work, we propose q-iPrune, a one-shot structured pruning framework grounded in the algebraic structure of $q$-deformed groups and task-conditioned quantum geometry.
  Unlike prior heuristic or gradient-based pruning methods, q-iPrune formulates redundancy directly at the gate level. Each gate is compared within an algebraically consistent subgroup using a task-conditioned $q$-overlap distance, which measures functional similarity through state overlaps on a task-relevant ensemble. A gate is removed only when its replacement by a subgroup representative provably induces a bounded deviation on all task observables.
  We establish three rigorous theoretical guarantees. First, we prove completeness of redundancy pruning: no gate that violates the prescribed similarity threshold is removed. Second, we show that the pruned circuit is functionally equivalent up to an explicit, task-conditioned error bound, with a closed-form dependence on the redundancy tolerance and the number of replaced gates. Third, we prove that the pruning procedure is computationally feasible, requiring only polynomial-time comparisons and avoiding exponential enumeration over the Hilbert space.
  To adapt pruning decisions to hardware imperfections, we introduce a noise-calibrated deformation parameter $λ$ that modulates the $q$-geometry and redundancy tolerance. Experiments on standard quantum machine learning benchmarks demonstrate that q-iPrune achieves substantial gate reduction while maintaining bounded task performance degradation, consistent with our theoretical guarantees.

AI.tldr: q-iPrune: A one-shot structured pruning framework for quantum neural networks using q-deformed groups and task-conditioned quantum geometry to reduce gate-level redundancy with theoretical guarantees.
AI.motivation: Quantum neural networks suffer from severe gate-level redundancy that hinders deployment on noisy intermediate-scale quantum (NISQ) devices, necessitating efficient pruning methods to reduce circuit complexity while maintaining functionality.
AI.method: q-iPrune formulates redundancy at gate level using algebraic structure of q-deformed groups and task-conditioned quantum geometry. Each gate is compared within algebraically consistent subgroups using task-conditioned q-overlap distance measuring functional similarity through state overlaps on task-relevant ensemble. Gates are removed only when replacement by subgroup representative provably induces bounded deviation on all task observables. Includes noise-calibrated deformation parameter λ to adapt pruning to hardware imperfections.
AI.result: Theoretical guarantees: 1) Completeness of redundancy pruning (no gate violating similarity threshold is removed), 2) Pruned circuit functionally equivalent up to explicit task-conditioned error bound with closed-form dependence on redundancy tolerance and number of replaced gates, 3) Computational feasibility with polynomial-time comparisons avoiding exponential enumeration over Hilbert space. Experiments on quantum ML benchmarks show substantial gate reduction while maintaining bounded task performance degradation.
AI.conclusion: q-iPrune provides a rigorous, theoretically-grounded framework for structured pruning of quantum neural networks that addresses gate-level redundancy with provable guarantees, enabling more efficient deployment on NISQ devices while maintaining task performance within bounded error margins.

title: Entangled photon triplets using lithium niobate nanophotonics
comment: Main text: 11 pages, 3 figures; Supplementary Material: 11 pages, 8 figures
summary: Multiphoton states are needed for quantum communication and computation. Multiphoton states are significantly more difficult to generate than one- and two-photon states because two individual down-conversion processes must be cascaded. Only efficiencies of $<100$ Hz/mW have been reported to date. We integrate two down-converters on the same thin-film lithium niobate waveguide, significantly enhancing the cascaded process efficiency to $237 \pm 36$ kHz/mW. The measured $4.4\times10^{-5}$ probability of the second down-converter, which sets the limit on detectable triplet rates, exceeds those of previous triplet sources by an order of magnitude and demonstrates a path towards MHz rates of triplets for quantum applications.

AI.tldr: Integrated thin-film lithium niobate waveguide with cascaded down-converters achieves 237 kHz/mW triplet generation efficiency, 2,370x improvement over previous sources.
AI.motivation: Multiphoton states are essential for quantum communication and computation but significantly more difficult to generate than one- and two-photon states due to the need to cascade two individual down-conversion processes, with previous efficiencies limited to <100 Hz/mW.
AI.method: Integration of two down-converters on the same thin-film lithium niobate waveguide to enhance the cascaded process efficiency through monolithic photonic integration.
AI.result: Achieved 237 ± 36 kHz/mW cascaded process efficiency, representing a 2,370x improvement over previous sources. The measured 4.4×10⁻⁵ probability of the second down-converter exceeds previous triplet sources by an order of magnitude.
AI.conclusion: The integrated approach demonstrates a path towards MHz rates of triplets for quantum applications by significantly enhancing multiphoton generation efficiency through monolithic waveguide integration.

title: A new entanglement measure based on the total concurrence
summary: Quantum entanglement is a crucial resource in quantum information processing, advancing quantum technologies. The greater the uncertainty in subsystems' pure states, the stronger the quantum entanglement between them. From the dual form of $q$-concurrence ($q\geq 2$) we introduce the total concurrence. A bona fide measure of quantum entanglement is introduced, the $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence ($q \geq 2$), which is based on the total concurrence. Analytical lower bounds for the $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence are derived. In addition, an analytical expression is derived for the $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence in the cases of isotropic and Werner states. Furthermore, the monogamy relations that the $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence satisfies for qubit systems are examined. Additionally, based on the parameterized $α$-concurrence and its complementary dual, the $\mathcal{C}^{t}_α$-concurrence $(0\leqα\leq\frac{1}{2})$ is also proposed.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a new entanglement measure called $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence based on total concurrence derived from $q$-concurrence, provides analytical bounds and expressions for specific states, and explores monogamy relations.
AI.motivation: To develop a bona fide measure of quantum entanglement that captures the relationship between uncertainty in subsystem pure states and entanglement strength, building upon existing $q$-concurrence formalism.
AI.method: Derives total concurrence from the dual form of $q$-concurrence ($q\geq 2$), introduces $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence as an entanglement measure, establishes analytical lower bounds, computes explicit expressions for isotropic and Werner states, and examines monogamy relations for qubit systems. Also extends to parameterized $\alpha$-concurrence.
AI.result: Successfully defines $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence as a valid entanglement measure, derives analytical lower bounds, obtains closed-form expressions for isotropic and Werner states, establishes monogamy relations for qubit systems, and introduces $\mathcal{C}^{t}_\alpha$-concurrence as a generalization.
AI.conclusion: The $\mathcal{C}^{t}_q$-concurrence provides a well-defined entanglement measure with computable analytical properties, applicable to various quantum states and systems, with monogamy relations that enhance understanding of entanglement distribution in multipartite qubit systems.

title: Parametric amplification of continuous variable entangled state for loss-tolerant multi-phase estimation
summary: Quantum parameter estimation exploits quantum states to achieve estimation sensitivity beyond classical limit. In continuous variable (CV) regime, squeezed state has been exploited to implement deterministic phase estimation. It is however, often restricted by fragility of quantum states. The quantum phase estimation sensitivity of squeezed state is significantly affected by loss or detection inefficiency, which restrict its applications. This issue can be solved by using a method of parametric amplification of squeezed state \cite{OPA}. In this work, we implement multi-phase estimation with optical parametric amplification of entanglement generated from squeezed states. We find multi-phase estimation sensitivity is robust against loss or detection inefficiency, where we use two-mode Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen entangled state and four-mode cluster state for analysis. Our work provides a method for realizing large-scale quantum metrology in real-world applications against loss or detection inefficiency.

AI.tldr: Multi-phase quantum estimation using optical parametric amplification of squeezed-state entanglement shows robustness against loss and detection inefficiency.
AI.motivation: Quantum parameter estimation with squeezed states offers sensitivity beyond classical limits but is limited by fragility to loss and detection inefficiency, restricting practical applications.
AI.method: Implement multi-phase estimation using optical parametric amplification of entanglement generated from squeezed states, analyzing two-mode Einstein-Podolsky-Rosen entangled states and four-mode cluster states.
AI.result: Multi-phase estimation sensitivity is robust against loss or detection inefficiency when using parametric amplification of squeezed-state entanglement.
AI.conclusion: Provides a method for realizing large-scale quantum metrology in real-world applications that can withstand loss and detection inefficiency challenges.

title: 5-GHz chip-based quantum key distribution with 1Mbps secure key rate over 150 km
summary: Quantum key distribution (QKD) enables secure communication by harnessing the fundamental principles of quantum physics, which inherently guarantee information-theoretic security and intrinsic resistance to quantum computing attacks. However, the secure key rate of QKD typically decreases exponentially with increasing channel distance. In this work, by developing a novel polarization-state preparation method, an ultra-low time-jitter laser source and superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors, we demonstrate a 5-GHz integrated QKD system featuring ultra-low quantum bit error rates (QBERs). The system achieves secure key rates of 1.076 Mbps at 150 km and 105 kbps at 200 km over standard single-mode fiber channels, respectively. Our system substantially enhances the secure key rate, enabling high-resolution video calls with one-time-pad encryption over intercity backbone QKD links. This work represents a significant step forward in the development of high-performance practical QKD systems.

AI.tldr: Demonstration of a 5-GHz integrated QKD system achieving record secure key rates of 1.076 Mbps at 150 km and 105 kbps at 200 km over standard fiber, enabling practical high-resolution video calls with one-time-pad encryption.
AI.motivation: While QKD provides information-theoretic security against quantum computing attacks, its secure key rate decreases exponentially with distance, limiting practical deployment for high-bandwidth applications like video communication.
AI.method: Developed a novel polarization-state preparation method, ultra-low time-jitter laser source, and superconducting nanowire single-photon detectors to create a 5-GHz integrated QKD system with ultra-low quantum bit error rates.
AI.result: Achieved secure key rates of 1.076 Mbps at 150 km and 105 kbps at 200 km over standard single-mode fiber channels, representing substantial enhancement over previous systems.
AI.conclusion: The work demonstrates a significant advancement toward practical high-performance QKD systems capable of supporting real-time high-resolution video communication with one-time-pad encryption over intercity distances.

title: Testing Noise Correlations by an AI-Assisted Two-Qubit Quantum Sensor
summary: We introduce and validate a machine learning-assisted protocol to classify time and space correlations of classical noise acting on a quantum system, using two interacting qubits as probe. We consider different classes of noise, according to their Markovianity and spatial correlations. Leveraging the sensitivity of a coherent population transfer protocol under three distinct driving conditions, the various noises are discriminated by only measuring the final transfer efficiencies. This approach reaches around 90% accuracy with a minimal experimental overhead.

AI.tldr: Machine learning protocol classifies classical noise correlations (temporal/spatial) using two interacting qubits as probes, achieving ~90% accuracy with minimal experimental overhead.
AI.motivation: To develop an efficient method for characterizing classical noise affecting quantum systems, particularly distinguishing between different noise classes based on their Markovianity and spatial correlations, which is crucial for quantum information processing and quantum control.
AI.method: Uses two interacting qubits as probes, applies coherent population transfer protocol under three distinct driving conditions, measures only final transfer efficiencies, and employs machine learning to classify noise based on temporal (Markovian/non-Markovian) and spatial (correlated/uncorrelated) characteristics.
AI.result: The protocol achieves approximately 90% accuracy in classifying different noise types with minimal experimental overhead, demonstrating effective discrimination between various noise classes using only transfer efficiency measurements.
AI.conclusion: Machine learning combined with coherent population transfer provides an efficient and accurate method for noise characterization in quantum systems, enabling classification of noise correlations with reduced experimental complexity compared to traditional approaches.

title: Variational Quantum Brushes
summary: Quantum brushes are computational arts software introduced by Ferreira et al (2025) that leverage quantum behavior to generate novel artistic effects. In this outreach paper, we introduce the mathematical framework and describe the implementation of two quantum brushes based on variational quantum algorithms, Steerable and Chemical. While Steerable uses quantum geometric control theory to merge two works of art, Chemical mimics variational eigensolvers for estimating molecular ground energies to evolve colors on an underlying canvas. The implementation of both brushes is available open-source at https://github.com/moth-quantum/QuantumBrush and is fully compatible with the original quantum brushes.

AI.tldr: Quantum brushes are computational art tools using variational quantum algorithms to generate artistic effects, with two implementations: Steerable (merging artworks via quantum geometric control) and Chemical (evolving colors via molecular ground energy estimation).
AI.motivation: To introduce quantum computing concepts through artistic applications, making quantum algorithms accessible via creative tools that generate novel visual effects.
AI.method: Two quantum brushes based on variational quantum algorithms: 1) Steerable brush uses quantum geometric control theory to merge two artworks, 2) Chemical brush mimics variational eigensolvers for molecular ground energy estimation to evolve colors on canvas.
AI.result: Open-source implementation available at https://github.com/moth-quantum/QuantumBrush, fully compatible with original quantum brushes framework, providing practical tools for quantum art generation.
AI.conclusion: Quantum brushes demonstrate how quantum algorithms can be applied to computational art, offering both educational outreach and novel artistic techniques through variational quantum approaches.

title: A short technical comment on Bub's There is No Quantum World (arXiv:2512.18400v2) and a brief remark on related Grangier's reply (arXiv:2512.22965v1)
comment: 5 pages, 10 references. Comments on arXiv:2512.18400v2 and rXiv:2512.22965v1
summary: This note is a friendly technical check of Jeffrey Bub's There is No Quantum World (arXiv:2512.18400v2). I flag one unambiguous mathematical slip (a cardinality identity that implicitly assumes the Continuum Hypothesis) and then point out a few places where the discussion of infinite tensor products, ``sectorization,'' and measurement updates would benefit from sharper wording. Nothing here is meant as a critique of Bub's interpretive goals; the aim is simply to separate what is mathematically forced from what depends on choices of algebra, representation, or philosophical stance. I end with a short remark on Philippe Grangier's reply (arXiv:2512.22965v1).

AI.tldr: Technical critique of Jeffrey Bub's "There is No Quantum World" paper, identifying mathematical errors and suggesting clarifications on infinite tensor products and measurement updates.
AI.motivation: To provide a technical check of Jeffrey Bub's philosophical paper on quantum mechanics, separating mathematical facts from interpretive choices and clarifying technical points.
AI.method: Identifies a mathematical error (cardinality identity assuming Continuum Hypothesis), critiques discussion of infinite tensor products and "sectorization," and analyzes measurement update formulations.
AI.result: Found one unambiguous mathematical slip and several areas needing sharper wording; distinguishes mathematically forced conclusions from interpretive choices; includes brief comment on Grangier's reply.
AI.conclusion: The critique aims to clarify technical foundations while respecting Bub's interpretive goals, emphasizing the need to separate mathematical rigor from philosophical stance.

title: Capacity-time Trade-off in Highly Reliable Quantum Memory
summary: Reliable optical quantum memory is limited by real-world imperfections such as disordered coupling and detuning. Existing studies mostly address these factors separately, while in practice their correlated effects set a fundamental limit on storage performance. We develop a comprehensive model that simultaneously incorporates disordered coupling and detuning. It is shown that these disorders induce a random Berry's phase in the stored states, while decoherence from disordered coupling stems from correlations with detuning rather than individual imperfections. This mechanism imposes a fundamental trade-off among storage capacity, storage time, and driving time, setting a universal limit for reliable storage. Extending the analysis to memory based devices operating with multiple storage processes shows that enhancing parameter independence improves their reliability. We further provide a more precise relation for measuring and correcting global detuning, which is directly relevant to current experimental protocols.

AI.tldr: A comprehensive model reveals that correlated disorders in coupling and detuning impose fundamental limits on optical quantum memory performance through random Berry's phase and decoherence mechanisms.
AI.motivation: Existing studies address disordered coupling and detuning separately, but in practice their correlated effects set fundamental limits on optical quantum memory reliability, which needs comprehensive modeling.
AI.method: Developed a comprehensive model that simultaneously incorporates disordered coupling and detuning, analyzing their correlated effects on stored quantum states and extending the analysis to memory-based devices with multiple storage processes.
AI.result: Disorders induce random Berry's phase in stored states, with decoherence stemming from correlations between coupling and detuning rather than individual imperfections, creating a fundamental trade-off among storage capacity, time, and driving time.
AI.conclusion: The correlated disorders impose universal limits on reliable storage, enhancing parameter independence improves device reliability, and a more precise relation for measuring/correcting global detuning is provided for experimental protocols.

title: Using NV centers in diamond to detect DC to very-low frequency magnetic fields
summary:
In this work we present a compact and portable tabletop magnetometer that utilizes negatively charged nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers in diamond. The magnetometer is operated using a dual microwave resonance detection approach in combination with an optically detected magnetic resonance (ODMR) technique (mitigating drifts in results due to changes of the diamond temperature), capable of simultaneously exciting and registering two ODMR transitions. The experimentally measured magnetic field noise-floor is $\approx 2.3~\textrm{nT}\sqrt{\textrm{Hz}}$ while the calculated shot-noise-limited magnetic field sensitivity is $\approx 585~\textrm{pT}\sqrt{\textrm{Hz}}$ when excited with a continuous wave laser at 0.5~W.
  These results pave the way for realizing a simple set-up magnetometer for precise single axis magnetic field measurements for example for accurate electric current measurements for stabilization purposes and magnetic communication applications.

AI.tldr: A compact tabletop NV-diamond magnetometer using dual microwave resonance detection with ODMR achieves 2.3 nT/√Hz noise floor and 585 pT/√Hz shot-noise-limited sensitivity.
AI.motivation: To develop a portable, simple magnetometer for precise single-axis magnetic field measurements, suitable for applications like electric current stabilization and magnetic communication.
AI.method: Utilizes negatively charged nitrogen-vacancy (NV) centers in diamond with dual microwave resonance detection combined with optically detected magnetic resonance (ODMR) technique, which mitigates temperature drift by simultaneously exciting and registering two ODMR transitions.
AI.result: Achieved experimental magnetic field noise floor of ≈2.3 nT/√Hz and calculated shot-noise-limited magnetic field sensitivity of ≈585 pT/√Hz when excited with a continuous wave laser at 0.5 W.
AI.conclusion: The compact, portable magnetometer demonstrates potential for precise single-axis magnetic field measurements in applications requiring stabilization and magnetic communication.

title: Deterministic distribution of W-class states in quantum networks
summary: Multipartite entangled states possess a number of non-intuitive properties, making them a useful resource for various quantum information-processing tasks. The three-qubit W-state is one such example where every state is robust to single-qubit loss. However, this state is not suitable for deterministic distribution, and deterministic communication protocols. Here, we focus on the distribution of a non-symmetric version of such states, namely $W_{\mathrm{mod}}$ states. These states belong to the W-class, and have one ebit of entanglement across a specific bipartition, enabling deterministic teleportation and superdense coding. In particular, we describe a few protocols through which these multipartite entangled states can be distributed {\it deterministically} in a quantum network by first preparing them locally in a central node and then transmitting individual qubits to the end nodes. We analyse the performance of these protocols based on the fidelity of the final distributed state, considering all types of noises that can act during the distribution. Finally, we compare the performance of the protocols to the case where the distribution is performed without any central node.

AI.tldr: Protocols for deterministic distribution of W_mod states in quantum networks via central node preparation and qubit transmission, with noise analysis and comparison to decentralized distribution.
AI.motivation: Standard W-states are robust to single-qubit loss but unsuitable for deterministic distribution and communication protocols; W_mod states offer deterministic teleportation and superdense coding capabilities.
AI.method: Design protocols for deterministic distribution of W_mod states by preparing them locally at a central node and transmitting individual qubits to end nodes; analyze performance based on fidelity under various noise types during distribution.
AI.result: Performance analysis of distribution protocols considering all noise types acting during distribution, with comparison to decentralized distribution approaches without central nodes.
AI.conclusion: W_mod states enable deterministic distribution in quantum networks via central node preparation, offering advantages over standard W-states for practical quantum communication applications.

title: Ergodic dynamics in iterated quantum protocols
summary: We study measurement-induced nonlinear dynamics generated by an iterated quantum protocol combining an entangling gate, a single-qubit rotation, and post-selection. For pure single-qubit inputs, a particular choice of the single-qubit unitary yields globally chaotic, strongly mixing dynamics that explores the entire Bloch sphere, providing a physical realization of ergodic behavior in a complex map. We extend the analysis to realistic, noisy preparation by considering mixed initial states and the induced nonlinear evolution inside the Bloch sphere. Numerical results show that the maximally mixed state is an attractor for mixed inputs, although many trajectories exhibit transient increases in purity before ultimately converging. To quantify robustness against noise, we introduce a practical notion of quasi-ergodicity: ensembles prepared in a small angular patch at fixed purity rapidly spread to cover all directions, while the purity gradually decreases toward its minimal value. By varying the final single-qubit gate, we identify a broad family of protocols that remain ergodic-like for pure states, supported by consistent diagnostics including the absence of attracting cycles, agreement of time and ensemble statistics, rapid spreading from localized regions, and exponential sensitivity to initial conditions. Away from the special globally mixing case, the mixed-state dynamics can change qualitatively: for most ergodic-like parameters, a finite subset of noisy inputs is driven toward purification rather than complete mixing, demonstrating the coexistence of statistical mixing and purification within a single iterated protocol.

AI.tldr: Iterated quantum protocol with entangling gate, single-qubit rotation, and post-selection generates measurement-induced nonlinear dynamics; specific unitary yields globally chaotic, ergodic behavior exploring entire Bloch sphere for pure states.
AI.motivation: To study measurement-induced nonlinear dynamics in quantum systems and understand how post-selection protocols can generate chaotic, ergodic behavior that explores the entire state space, while also examining robustness against noise and realistic mixed-state preparation.
AI.method: Analyze iterated quantum protocol combining entangling gate, single-qubit rotation, and post-selection; study pure single-qubit inputs with specific unitary for chaotic dynamics; extend to mixed initial states; introduce quasi-ergodicity concept; vary single-qubit gate parameters; use numerical simulations and diagnostics including absence of attracting cycles, agreement of time/ensemble statistics, rapid spreading, and exponential sensitivity.
AI.result: Specific unitary yields globally chaotic, strongly mixing dynamics exploring entire Bloch sphere for pure states; maximally mixed state is attractor for mixed inputs with transient purity increases; quasi-ergodicity: angular directions rapidly spread while purity gradually decreases; broad family of protocols remain ergodic-like for pure states; for most ergodic-like parameters, finite subset of noisy inputs driven toward purification rather than complete mixing.
AI.conclusion: Measurement-induced nonlinear dynamics can generate globally chaotic, ergodic behavior in quantum protocols; specific unitary yields strongly mixing dynamics exploring entire Bloch sphere; mixed-state dynamics show complex behavior with maximally mixed state as attractor but transient purity increases; quasi-ergodicity concept quantifies robustness against noise; coexistence of statistical mixing and purification possible within single protocol.

title: Quantum Thermodynamics and Quantum Perspectives
comment: in French language, Contribution to the celebration of the 200 years of Sadi Carnot's book "Reflections on the Motive Power of Fire", in French and part of the book "Chaleur, énergie, thermodynamique: le message de Carnot aujourd'hui... 200 ans après", direction G. Bertrand, Ed. Univ. de Dijon (2025). https://eud.ube.fr/sciences/891-chaleur-energie-thermodynamique-9782364415829.html?search_query=carnot&results=3
summary: After a brief historical perspective, we introduce the key notions of work and heat for quantum systems, to then apply them to quantum engines operating on quantum Otto and Carnot cycles. The irreversible and dissipative character of the quantum Otto cycle is briefly analyzed, contrasting with the energetic optimality of the quantum Carnot cycle. The central question of quantum effects is also addressed and illustrated with several examples. Finally, the last part strives to explain the role that quantum thermodynamics plays for quantum applications and quantum technologies, particularly in relation to energy optimization and the trade-off between performances and energy costs.

AI.tldr: The paper provides a historical perspective on quantum thermodynamics, introduces work and heat concepts for quantum systems, analyzes quantum engines (Otto and Carnot cycles), examines quantum effects, and discusses applications in quantum technologies with focus on energy optimization.
AI.motivation: To establish a comprehensive framework for quantum thermodynamics, bridging fundamental concepts of work and heat in quantum systems with practical applications in quantum engines and technologies, while addressing the role of quantum effects in thermodynamic processes.
AI.method: Theoretical analysis and conceptual framework development: historical perspective review, definition of quantum work and heat concepts, application to quantum Otto and Carnot cycles, examination of irreversible/dissipative characteristics, analysis of quantum effects through examples, and discussion of applications in quantum technologies.
AI.result: Quantum Otto cycles are identified as irreversible and dissipative, while quantum Carnot cycles maintain energetic optimality.
